title: Doubtless Understanding of Krishna | HG Chanchalapathi Dasa | SB 5 .1.4 | 21.06.2024
speaker: HG Chanchalapathi Dasa

segments.key_quote: A Grihavrata, one who has taken a vow to execute family duties, has no chance to become Krishna conscious.
segments.summary: King Pariksit expresses his doubt about how someone attached to family can become Krishna conscious, referencing Prahlada Maharaj's statement about Grihavratas.

segments.key_quote: This is very surprising that he became Krishne Mathihi. He became attached to Krishna. Became Krishna conscious.
segments.summary: The speaker explains King Pariksit's question about how Priyavrata, despite being attached to family, achieved perfection in Krishna consciousness (Krishne Mathihi).

segments.key_quote: There should be a search for perfection in human life...Should be the dominant aspect of human life.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of the quest for perfection in human life, noting that without spiritual knowledge, people often misinterpret what true perfection is.

segments.key_quote: But then, where is he now? Where is that person?
segments.summary: The speaker illustrates the transience of material achievements like power and fame by referencing historical figures like Mahatma Gandhi and Napoleon, questioning their current relevance.

segments.key_quote: Krishna has all these opulences to an unlimited extent. And hence, He becomes captivating.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that we are naturally attracted to power, influence, and fame, and that Krishna, possessing all these qualities to an unlimited extent, is the ultimate object of attraction.

segments.key_quote: When your consciousness is attached to Krishna, that is Siddhi. That is the infallible perfection.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates that Krishna is all-attractive and that achieving perfection (Siddhi) means having one's consciousness attached to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: If our consciousness becomes absorbed, consciousness becomes attached, to Krishna, that is considered to be Siddhirabhut.
segments.summary: The speaker references Prahlada Maharaj's words and emphasizes that Krishna consciousness is a development in our consciousness, and perfection is achieved when our consciousness is attached to Krishna.

segments.key_quote: Just like we have to be devoted, to our partial cause, Father and mother, we should also be, Absolutely devoted, To our absolute cause, Krishna.
segments.summary: The speaker draws an analogy between devotion to parents (partial cause) and devotion to Krishna (absolute cause), arguing that we should be absolutely devoted to Krishna as our ultimate source.

segments.key_quote: Becoming Krishnamatihi, Who is Krishna, Who we are, And becoming attached to Krishna...Is considered to be the highest, Perfection.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that devotion to Krishna is a function of enlightenment and that becoming absorbed in Krishna is the highest perfection, mentioning Srila Prabhupada's coining of the term 'Krishna consciousness' based on Rupa Goswami's expression.

segments.key_quote: Krishna bhakti is not a dry, Concept, No, it is full of, Rasa, It's full of juice, Krishna bhakti rasa, Bhavitha, Imbued, Absorbed, Immersed in, Matihi.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the concept of 'Krishna bhakti rasa bhavitha matihi,' emphasizing that Krishna bhakti is full of mellow and juice, and that being absorbed in it is the perfection of life.

segments.key_quote: Shukadeva Goswami's consciousness was, He was, Captivated, Charmed, By, Hare guna.
segments.summary: The speaker describes Shukadeva Goswami's consciousness as being captivated by the qualities of Lord Hari (Krishna), contrasting it with the materialistic person's attraction to trivial things.

segments.key_quote: At least to our, In our situation, We have at least boarded the, Train, Which is, Heading in the right, Which will head in the right direction.
segments.summary: The speaker shares an anecdote about Prabhupada and emphasizes that devotees have at least boarded the 'train' of Krishna consciousness, heading in the right direction, and that one can develop that consciousness.

segments.key_quote: Look at the good fortune we all have. We have become part of that society which is going to teach us a certain consciousness which is described in the Vedic literature as the highest perfection.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates that Krishnamatihi (Krishna consciousness) is perfection and expresses gratitude for being part of a society that teaches this consciousness, which is described in Vedic literature.

segments.key_quote: Krishna is actually explaining what does the way all of the Vedic literatures finally boil down to. What is the final statement?
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verses from the 15th chapter of Bhagavad Gita, where Krishna explains the essence of Vedic literature and the concept of Purushottama, distinguishing between Kshara and Akshara purushas.

segments.key_quote: There is one more third purusha who is anya, different from these kshara and akshara purushas and he is uttama purusha.
segments.summary: The speaker continues explaining the Bhagavad Gita verses, highlighting the existence of a third Purusha, Uttama Purusha (Purushottama), who is transcendental to both Kshara and Akshara, and is celebrated as Paramatma.

segments.key_quote: One who knows Krishna as that supreme personality doubtlessly...He renders devotional service unto me.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that one who doubtlessly knows Krishna as the Purushottama renders devotional service to Him with all their heart and devotion.

segments.key_quote: One who has understood that, yes, why I have landed in the prison, and I must get out of the prison, by becoming a law-abiding citizen, he has understood the right thing.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a prison to illustrate that true understanding lies in recognizing why we are in the material world and striving to reform ourselves to attain liberation.

segments.key_quote: The material world is there, it's an opportunity for reformation, to understand our relation with the supreme.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the material world is an opportunity for reformation and understanding our relationship with the Supreme, contrasting it with merely acquiring worldly knowledge.

segments.key_quote: This understanding Arjuna, is the confidential part, of all Vedic literature.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that understanding Krishna as the Purushottama and rendering service to Him is the most confidential part of all Vedic literature.

segments.key_quote: To everybody, we will show the Paduka, but, real Paduka inside, only a few, you are few people, this is called confidential.
segments.summary: The speaker shares an anecdote about the upcoming Paduka festival, illustrating the concept of confidentiality by mentioning that the actual wooden Padukas of Chaitanya Mahaprabhu will only be shown to a select few.

segments.key_quote: If you understand this, in this way...you will become an intelligent person...he has attained perfection.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates that understanding Krishna as the Purushottama is confidential knowledge, and that understanding this makes one intelligent and leads to perfection, contrasting it with superficial knowledge.

segments.key_quote: Confidently knowing, Krishna is the supreme person, I must surrender to him, and that is perfection.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by emphasizing that confidently knowing Krishna as the Supreme Person and surrendering to Him is perfection, lamenting that many commentators miss this point, and highlighting the importance of Krishna consciousness.
